intro: Cnemidophacos toanus, commonly known as the Florida morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family, characterized by its twining stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically blooms in early spring, producing vibrant blue or purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its vines can grow up to several meters in length. Cnemidophacos toanus is often found in moist, shaded areas such as swamps and forest floors.
